trans-unit.source: Develop Java-based topologies for Apache Storm | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Develop Java-based topologies for Apache Storm | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to create Storm topologies in Java by creating a simple word count topology.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to create Storm topologies in Java by creating a simple word count topology.

trans-unit.source: Learn a basic process to create a Java-based topology for Apache Storm on HDInsight by using Maven.
trans-unit.target: Learn a basic process to create a Java-based topology for Apache Storm on HDInsight by using Maven.

trans-unit.source: You will walk through the process of creating a basic word-count application using Maven and Java.
trans-unit.target: You will walk through the process of creating a basic word-count application using Maven and Java.

trans-unit.source: Although instructions are provided for using Eclipse, you can also use the text editor of your choice.
trans-unit.target: Although instructions are provided for using Eclipse, you can also use the text editor of your choice.

trans-unit.source: After completing the steps in this document, you will have a basic topology that you can deploy to Apache Storm on HDInsight.
trans-unit.target: After completing the steps in this document, you will have a basic topology that you can deploy to Apache Storm on HDInsight.

trans-unit.source: Java Developer Kit (JDK) version 7
trans-unit.target: Java Developer Kit (JDK) version 7

trans-unit.source: Maven: Maven is a project build system for Java projects.
trans-unit.target: Maven: Maven is a project build system for Java projects.

trans-unit.source: A text editor such as Notepad, Emacs, Sublime Text, Atom.io, Brackets.io. Or you can use an integrated development environment (IDE) such as Eclipse (version Luna or later).
trans-unit.target: A text editor such as Notepad, Emacs, Sublime Text, Atom.io, Brackets.io. Or you can use an integrated development environment (IDE) such as Eclipse (version Luna or later).

trans-unit.source: Your editor or IDE may have specific functionality for working with Maven that is not addressed in this document.
trans-unit.target: Your editor or IDE may have specific functionality for working with Maven that is not addressed in this document.

trans-unit.source: For information about the capabilities of your editing environment, see the documentation for the product you are using.
trans-unit.target: For information about the capabilities of your editing environment, see the documentation for the product you are using.

trans-unit.source: The following environment variables may be set when you install Java and the JDK.
trans-unit.target: The following environment variables may be set when you install Java and the JDK.

trans-unit.source: However, you should check that they exist and that they contain the correct values for your system.
trans-unit.target: However, you should check that they exist and that they contain the correct values for your system.

trans-unit.source: JAVA_HOME - should point to the directory where the Java runtime environment (JRE) is installed.
trans-unit.target: JAVA_HOME - should point to the directory where the Java runtime environment (JRE) is installed.

trans-unit.source: For example, in a Unix or Linux distribution, it should have a value similar to /usr/lib/jvm/java-7-oracle.
trans-unit.target: For example, in a Unix or Linux distribution, it should have a value similar to /usr/lib/jvm/java-7-oracle.

trans-unit.source: In Windows, it would have a value similar to c:\Program Files (x86)\Java\jre1.7
trans-unit.target: In Windows, it would have a value similar to c:\Program Files (x86)\Java\jre1.7

trans-unit.source: PATH - should contain the following paths:
trans-unit.target: PATH - should contain the following paths:

trans-unit.source: JAVA_HOME (or the equivalent path)
trans-unit.target: JAVA_HOME (or the equivalent path)

trans-unit.source: JAVA_HOME\bin (or the equivalent path)
trans-unit.target: JAVA_HOME\bin (or the equivalent path)

trans-unit.source: The directory where Maven is installed
trans-unit.target: The directory where Maven is installed

trans-unit.source: From the command line, use the following code to create a new Maven project named WordCount:
trans-unit.target: From the command line, use the following code to create a new Maven project named WordCount:

trans-unit.source: This will create a new directory named WordCount at the current location, which contains a basic Maven project.
trans-unit.target: This will create a new directory named WordCount at the current location, which contains a basic Maven project.

trans-unit.source: The WordCount directory will contain the following items:
trans-unit.target: The WordCount directory will contain the following items:

trans-unit.source: pom.xml: Contains settings for the Maven project.
trans-unit.target: pom.xml: Contains settings for the Maven project.

trans-unit.source: src\main\java\com\microsoft\example: Contains your application code.
trans-unit.target: src\main\java\com\microsoft\example: Contains your application code.

trans-unit.source: src\test\java\com\microsoft\example: Contains tests for your application.
trans-unit.target: src\test\java\com\microsoft\example: Contains tests for your application.

trans-unit.source: For this example, we will not be creating tests.
trans-unit.target: For this example, we will not be creating tests.

trans-unit.source: Because we will be creating our application, delete the generated test and the application files:
trans-unit.target: Because we will be creating our application, delete the generated test and the application files:

trans-unit.source: src\test\java\com\microsoft\example\AppTest.java
trans-unit.target: src\test\java\com\microsoft\example\AppTest.java

trans-unit.source: src\main\java\com\microsoft\example\App.java
trans-unit.target: src\main\java\com\microsoft\example\App.java

trans-unit.source: Because this is a Storm topology, you must add a dependency for Storm components.
trans-unit.target: Because this is a Storm topology, you must add a dependency for Storm components.

trans-unit.source: Open the pom.xml file and add the following code in the <dependencies> section:
trans-unit.target: Open the pom.xml file and add the following code in the <dependencies> section:

trans-unit.source: At compile time, Maven uses this information to look up storm-core in the Maven repository.
trans-unit.target: At compile time, Maven uses this information to look up storm-core in the Maven repository.

trans-unit.source: It first looks in the repository on your local computer.
trans-unit.target: It first looks in the repository on your local computer.

trans-unit.source: If the files aren't there, it will download them from the public Maven repository and store them in the local repository.
trans-unit.target: If the files aren't there, it will download them from the public Maven repository and store them in the local repository.

trans-unit.source: Notice the provided line in the section we added.
trans-unit.target: Notice the provided line in the section we added.

trans-unit.source: This tells Maven to exclude storm-core from any JAR files we create, because it will be provided by the system.
trans-unit.target: This tells Maven to exclude storm-core from any JAR files we create, because it will be provided by the system.

trans-unit.source: This allows the packages you create to be a little smaller, and it ensures that they will use the storm-core bits that are included in the Storm on HDInsight cluster.
trans-unit.target: This allows the packages you create to be a little smaller, and it ensures that they will use the storm-core bits that are included in the Storm on HDInsight cluster.

trans-unit.source: Maven plug-ins allow you to customize the build stages of the project, such as how the project is compiled or how to package it into a JAR file. Open the pom.xml file and add the following code directly above the line.
trans-unit.target: Maven plug-ins allow you to customize the build stages of the project, such as how the project is compiled or how to package it into a JAR file. Open the pom.xml file and add the following code directly above the line.

trans-unit.source: This section will be used to add plug-ins and other build configuration options.
trans-unit.target: This section will be used to add plug-ins and other build configuration options.

trans-unit.source: For Storm topologies, the Exec Maven Plugin is useful because it allows you to easily run the topology locally in your development environment. Add the following to the section of the pom.xml file to include the Exec Maven plugin:
trans-unit.target: For Storm topologies, the Exec Maven Plugin is useful because it allows you to easily run the topology locally in your development environment. Add the following to the section of the pom.xml file to include the Exec Maven plugin:

trans-unit.source: Another useful plug-in is the Apache Maven Compiler Plugin, which is used to change compilation options.
trans-unit.target: Another useful plug-in is the Apache Maven Compiler Plugin, which is used to change compilation options.

trans-unit.source: The primary reason we need this is to change the Java version that Maven uses for the source and target for your application.
trans-unit.target: The primary reason we need this is to change the Java version that Maven uses for the source and target for your application.

trans-unit.source: We want version 1.7.
trans-unit.target: We want version 1.7.

trans-unit.source: Add the following in the section of the pom.xml file to include the Apache Maven Compiler plugin and set the source and target versions to 1.7.
trans-unit.target: Add the following in the section of the pom.xml file to include the Apache Maven Compiler plugin and set the source and target versions to 1.7.

trans-unit.source: A Java-based Storm topology consists of three components that you must author (or reference) as a dependency.
trans-unit.target: A Java-based Storm topology consists of three components that you must author (or reference) as a dependency.

trans-unit.source: Spouts: Reads data from external sources and emits streams of data into the topology.
trans-unit.target: Spouts: Reads data from external sources and emits streams of data into the topology.

trans-unit.source: Bolts: Performs processing on streams emitted by spouts or other bolts, and emits one or more streams.
trans-unit.target: Bolts: Performs processing on streams emitted by spouts or other bolts, and emits one or more streams.

trans-unit.source: Topology: Defines how the spouts and bolts are arranged, and provides the entry point for the topology.
trans-unit.target: Topology: Defines how the spouts and bolts are arranged, and provides the entry point for the topology.

trans-unit.source: To reduce requirements for setting up external data sources, the following spout simply emits random sentences.
trans-unit.target: To reduce requirements for setting up external data sources, the following spout simply emits random sentences.

trans-unit.source: It is a modified version of a spout that is provided with the (Storm-Starter examples).
trans-unit.target: It is a modified version of a spout that is provided with the (Storm-Starter examples).

trans-unit.source: For an example of a spout that reads from an external data source, see one of the following examples:
trans-unit.target: For an example of a spout that reads from an external data source, see one of the following examples:

trans-unit.source: TwitterSampleSpout: An example spout that reads from Twitter
trans-unit.target: TwitterSampleSpout: An example spout that reads from Twitter

trans-unit.source: Storm-Kafka: A spout that reads from Kafka
trans-unit.target: Storm-Kafka: A spout that reads from Kafka

trans-unit.source: For the spout, create a new file named RandomSentenceSpout.java in the src\main\java\com\microsoft\example directory and use the following as the contents:
trans-unit.target: For the spout, create a new file named RandomSentenceSpout.java in the src\main\java\com\microsoft\example directory and use the following as the contents:

trans-unit.source: Take a moment to read through the code comments to understand how this spout works.
trans-unit.target: Take a moment to read through the code comments to understand how this spout works.

trans-unit.source: Although this topology uses only one spout, others may have several that feed data from different sources into the topology.
trans-unit.target: Although this topology uses only one spout, others may have several that feed data from different sources into the topology.

trans-unit.source: Bolts handle the data processing.
trans-unit.target: Bolts handle the data processing.

trans-unit.source: For this topology, we have two bolts:
trans-unit.target: For this topology, we have two bolts:

trans-unit.source: SplitSentence: Splits the sentences emitted by RandomSentenceSpout into individual words.
trans-unit.target: SplitSentence: Splits the sentences emitted by RandomSentenceSpout into individual words.

trans-unit.source: WordCount: Counts how many times each word has occurred.
trans-unit.target: WordCount: Counts how many times each word has occurred.

trans-unit.source: Bolts can do literally anything, for example, computation, persistence, or talking to external components.
trans-unit.target: Bolts can do literally anything, for example, computation, persistence, or talking to external components.

trans-unit.source: Create two new files, SplitSentence.java and WordCount.Java in the src\main\java\com\microsoft\example directory.
trans-unit.target: Create two new files, SplitSentence.java and WordCount.Java in the src\main\java\com\microsoft\example directory.

trans-unit.source: Use the following as the contents for the files:
trans-unit.target: Use the following as the contents for the files:

trans-unit.source: SplitSentence
trans-unit.target: SplitSentence

trans-unit.source: WordCount
trans-unit.target: WordCount

trans-unit.source: Take a moment to read through the code comments to understand how each bolt works.
trans-unit.target: Take a moment to read through the code comments to understand how each bolt works.

trans-unit.source: The topology ties the spouts and bolts together into a graph, which defines how data flows between the components.
trans-unit.target: The topology ties the spouts and bolts together into a graph, which defines how data flows between the components.

trans-unit.source: It also provides parallelism hints that Storm uses when creating instances of the components within the cluster.
trans-unit.target: It also provides parallelism hints that Storm uses when creating instances of the components within the cluster.

trans-unit.source: The following is a basic diagram of the graph of components for this topology.
trans-unit.target: The following is a basic diagram of the graph of components for this topology.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>diagram showing the spouts and bolts arrangement</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>diagram showing the spouts and bolts arrangement</linkText>

trans-unit.source: To implement the topology, create a new file named WordCountTopology.java in the src\main\java\com\microsoft\example directory.
trans-unit.target: To implement the topology, create a new file named WordCountTopology.java in the src\main\java\com\microsoft\example directory.

trans-unit.source: Use the following as the contents for the file:
trans-unit.target: Use the following as the contents for the file:

trans-unit.source: Take a moment to read through the code comments to understand how the topology is defined and then submitted to the cluster.
trans-unit.target: Take a moment to read through the code comments to understand how the topology is defined and then submitted to the cluster.

trans-unit.source: After you save the files, use the following command to test the topology locally.
trans-unit.target: After you save the files, use the following command to test the topology locally.

trans-unit.source: As it runs, the topology will display startup information.
trans-unit.target: As it runs, the topology will display startup information.

trans-unit.source: Then it begins to display lines similar to the following as sentences are emitted from the spout and processed by the bolts.
trans-unit.target: Then it begins to display lines similar to the following as sentences are emitted from the spout and processed by the bolts.

trans-unit.source: As you can see from this output, the following occurred:
trans-unit.target: As you can see from this output, the following occurred:

trans-unit.source: Spout emits "an apple a day keeps the doctor away."
trans-unit.target: Spout emits "an apple a day keeps the doctor away."

trans-unit.source: Split bolt begins emitting individual words from the sentence.
trans-unit.target: Split bolt begins emitting individual words from the sentence.

trans-unit.source: Count bolt begins emitting each word and how many times it has been emitted.
trans-unit.target: Count bolt begins emitting each word and how many times it has been emitted.

trans-unit.source: By looking at the data emitted by the count bolt, we can see that 'apple' has been emitted 53 times.
trans-unit.target: By looking at the data emitted by the count bolt, we can see that 'apple' has been emitted 53 times.

trans-unit.source: The count will continue to go up as long as the topology runs because the same sentences are randomly emitted over and over and the count is never reset.
trans-unit.target: The count will continue to go up as long as the topology runs because the same sentences are randomly emitted over and over and the count is never reset.

trans-unit.source: Trident is a high-level abstraction that is provided by Storm.
trans-unit.target: Trident is a high-level abstraction that is provided by Storm.

trans-unit.source: It supports stateful processing.
trans-unit.target: It supports stateful processing.

trans-unit.source: The primary advantage of Trident is that it can guarantee that every message that enters the topology is processed only once.
trans-unit.target: The primary advantage of Trident is that it can guarantee that every message that enters the topology is processed only once.

trans-unit.source: This is difficult to achieve in a raw Java topology, which guarantee's that messages will be processed at least once.
trans-unit.target: This is difficult to achieve in a raw Java topology, which guarantee's that messages will be processed at least once.

trans-unit.source: There are also other differences, such as built-in components that can be used instead of creating bolts.
trans-unit.target: There are also other differences, such as built-in components that can be used instead of creating bolts.

trans-unit.source: In fact, bolts are completely replaced by less-generic components, such as filters, projections, and functions.
trans-unit.target: In fact, bolts are completely replaced by less-generic components, such as filters, projections, and functions.

trans-unit.source: Trident applications can be created by using Maven projects.
trans-unit.target: Trident applications can be created by using Maven projects.

trans-unit.source: You use the same basic steps as presented earlier in this article—only the code is different.
trans-unit.target: You use the same basic steps as presented earlier in this article—only the code is different.

trans-unit.source: For more information about Trident, see the Trident API Overview.
trans-unit.target: For more information about Trident, see the Trident API Overview.

trans-unit.source: For an example of a Trident application, see <linkText>Twitter trending topics with Apache Storm on HDInsight</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For an example of a Trident application, see <linkText>Twitter trending topics with Apache Storm on HDInsight</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: You have learned how to create a Storm topology by using Java.
trans-unit.target: You have learned how to create a Storm topology by using Java.
